summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against six defendants in a civil injunctive action brought by the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of South Dakota.  The SEC's complaint alleges that Tally Colombe, the former executive director of Hunkpati Investments, and her twin sister, Kristal Hawk, engaged in a long-running scheme to defraud the company out of millions of dollars.  According to the complaint, the defendants agreed to settle the charges without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint.  In a parallel action, the court also issued a temporary restraining order and issued an order freezing the defendants' assets, freezing their assets, and ordering them to pay restitution in the amount of $1,637.77.  On September 12, 2017, the SEC announced that it had obtained a court order freezing all assets held by the defendants, freezing the assets of all of them, and imposing a civil penalty of $39,997. The court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest of $2,829.77 and a $10,000 civil penalty for each defendant.  Following the SEC's investigation, the case was handled by Scott Shields, who was supervising the case. The case was supervised by Kelly L. Gibson, Chief of the Division of Enforcement's Criminal Division. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Missouri Attorney General's Office, and the Missouri Department of Insurance.  For further information, see SEC Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01221. Â On September 19, 2018, the Honorable Judge James A. Hardin granted the SEC request for a preliminary injunction against future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.   The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay.Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.
